awd_titl_txt: Building Capacity: Guiding Critical Transitions to the Baccalaureate
awd_abstract_narration:
The Improving Undergraduate STEM Education: Hispanic-Serving Institutions Program (HSI Program) aims to enhance undergraduate STEM education and build capacity at HSIs. Projects supported by the HSI Program will also generate new knowledge on how to achieve these aims. This project at Riverside City College will advance the aims of the HSI Program by developing and analyzing the impact of six interventions for Riverside College Promise Program students who have declared STEM majors. The interventions include a summer bridge program from high school to college, home courses, college and career workshops, research experiences, near-peer mentoring, and cross-enrollment courses. The project seeks to increase retention within STEM programs at Riverside City College as well as increase the transfer rates to baccalaureate STEM degrees at four-year institutions such as California State University, San Bernardino and the University of California, Riverside. Project collaborators from these institutions will lead summer research for Riverside City College students; faculty from the University of California, Irvine will conduct educational research related to the project. Through interventions and partnerships, this project seeks to increase undergraduate retention, enrollment, and graduation and transfer rates in STEM degree programs. 

This project will investigate the impact of a program and its sub-components on student academic performance and STEM degree attainment. The project seeks to determine the most critical components in improving student academic outcomes and persistence, particularly for low-income and traditionally underrepresented minorities. The project will also investigate factors essential to student success in navigating the critical transitions from high school to two-year college and from two-year college to four-year university. The project study will include a quantitative research component that employs a rigorous quasi-experimental design to understand the impact of the project on student academic outcomes. The project will gather data on the impact of the interventions on the rates of students earning a STEM baccalaureate degree. A qualitative research component will produce an understanding about how each sub-component contributes to an objective outcome measure and will ascertain perceptions about the sub-component, student involvement levels, and potential implementation barriers. Results of this research will be shared with other institutions seeking to build STEM degree programs via interventions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

inst.inst_name: Riverside Community College District/Riverside City College

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Riverside Community College District/Riverside City College

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of the STEM En Familia project was to help students, particularly Latinx first-generation students, transition from high school to Riverside City College, and then on to a local university. Support consisted of three interventions aimed at helping first-generation students become successful in a college academic setting:

1.    A summer bridge experience intended to give the students an orientation to the college and how to be a college student;

2.    Home Courses which are specially designed sections of STEM classes with emphasis on cohort/team building, contributions of Latinx researchers, and culturally relevant pedagogical approaches;

3.    A workshop series to help first generation college students navigate the college environment including general orientation information, introduction to faculty that were first-generation college students, and exposure to STEM students who have successfully transferred to local universities.

Additionally, three interventions were aimed at increasing transfer:

1.    A summer research experience where students complete a research project on a university campus;

2.     Near-peer mentorship from students who have successfully transferred within a STEM field;

3.    Cross-enrollment in a transfer university course while still enrolled at RCC.

The summer bridge and the cross-enrollment courses proved logistically challenging and were not fully implemented. However, the remaining interventions were fully implemented and had noticeable impacts. Students in Home Courses were 10.7% more likely to be retained semester to semester and 7.4% more likely to persist year to year than the average for STEM majors over the course of the project.

Home Course faculty incentivized attendance at success workshops and other campus events. Workshops were well attended and the student feedback indicated they felt encouraged and empowered by attending. Summer research experiences were 1-week projects designed to expose students to research in a structured environment assisted by a near-peer mentor. Student focus groups after summer research experiences indicate they had a powerful impact on student motivation and confidence, both in their ability to be a researcher and in their scientific skillset.

Home Courses and workshops are low-cost, easy to implement, and have a positive impact on students’ sense of belonging. Without specialized training, Home Course faculty focused on team-building, culturally relevant pedagogy, and real-world applications throughout their courses. Additionally, they connected their students to the existing STEM Engagement Center and associated supports, including success workshops. The 1-week summer research experiences offered through this project built the confidence of the participating students and encouraged them to pursue more traditional, summer-long research experiences. Additionally, these research experiences increased transfer motivation for participating students. Implementation of these interventions almost completely overlaps with the Covid-19 pandemic and campus closure. Despite the added challenges posed by the pandemic, these interventions were able to improve students’ sense of belonging, expand their understanding of STEM, improve their confidence, as well as retention and persistence rates during a time of profound national detachment from educational institutions.
